Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Attention-Aware Cyberlearning to Detect and Combat Inattentiveness During Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to concentrate on tasks is critical to learning. This project will develop attention-aware cyberlearning as a new genre of learning technologies that automatically detect and respond to students' attentional states. In particular, this project will implement technology that will detect mind wandering (MW) which is when attention shifts from task-related thoughts to task-unrelated thoughts. MW has been studied in the context of complex comprehension tasks and it has been found that a high degree of MW leads to inferior performance. However MW has not been studied in the context of learning with technology and technology solutions have not been proposed to reduce MW. This project addresses MW in the context of learning with technology. The detection of MW is through the use of inexpensive eye-tracking devices. The devices will be integrated with software to detect MW while students are engaged in learning high school biology through an interactive system called Guru. Once MW is detected, software strategies will be used to enable the students return to the learning task. The primary research will be in the development and testing of MW detection algorithms and in the development and testing of strategies to reduce MW.

In more detail, the attention-aware Guru will include an integrated eye tracker, an automated gaze-based MW detector, and intervention strategies to improve learning by mitigating the costs of MW. The research will be conducted in 9th grade biology classrooms in Northern Indiana, where the core technological components will be formatively studied, iteratively refined, and summatively evaluated. Generalizable insights will be identified at every stage of the project in order to promote transferability of the findings to future attention-aware technologies, thereby helping students learn to their fullest potential. In summary, the proposed attention-aware Guru technology will be used to advance fundamental research focused on uncovering: (1) the incidence of MW during learning with technology, (2) relationships between MW and learning, (3) patterns of eye-gaze that are diagnostic of MW, (4) automated intervention strategies to reorient attention and reduce the detrimental effects of MW, and (5) generalizable insights to catalyze future implementations of attention-aware cyberlearning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to blend basic research focused on why, when, and how minds wander with advances in eye tracking, mental state estimation, and conversational learning technologies to advance a new genre of attention-aware learning technologies that automatically detect and combat wandering minds. Our work is done in the context of the Guru biology cyberlearning technology, where a computer agent converses with students, gestures to virtual instructional materials with rich multimedia, and presents activities for extended practice and learning. We completed 20 integrated research activities, collected nine datasets in the lab and in classrooms, produced 49 publications (one of which received a best paper award at an international conference), and developed new techniques to detect and combat mind wandering (MW).

Our key intellectual contributions include:

  1. Advancing basic research on MW during cyberlearning. Our studies have shed light on the incidence of MW during cyberlearning, different types of attentional lapses (intentional or unintentional), the influence of individual differences and task context features on MW, and on associations between MW, learning, and retention.
  2. Developing a new paradigm of gaze tracking in classrooms. We demonstrated the feasibility of using consumer-off-the-shelf eye trackers for collecting good quality eye gaze data in real-world classrooms as dozens of students simultaneously interact with cyberlearning technologies. We then collected rich datasets of eye tracking data from approximately 500 students (about one hour of data from each) in authentic classroom environments, which we have used in this research and which we will release for future research.
  3. Fully-automated robust MW detectors in real-world contexts. We advanced basic research into what eye movements reveal about the priorities of the visual system and used these insights to develop reliable, accurate, and generalizable MW detectors. After extensive lab-based validation, the MW detectors were used to monitor MW in real-time and to trigger dynamic interventions (see below). We also compared gaze-based to face- based MW detectors, finding the former to be more accurate.
  4. Development and validation of attentional-aware cyberlearning technology. We designed, implemented, iteratively refined, and summatively evaluated the first cyberlearning technology that addresses mind wandering via real-time gaze-contingent interventions. In two summative classroom studies, we found that the interventions were successful in reducing MW, and in limited cases, improved retention compared to active- and do-nothing- controls.
  5. Generalizable insights to inform future of attention-aware cyberlearning. We have identified and documented generalizable findings and design recommendations for subsequent attention-aware cyberlearning technologies at multiple levels ranging from the hardware, to attention tracking, to the learning activities, to the interventions themselves.

Thus, our project enhances the field of cyberlearning (by building the first technology to automatically detect and respond to MW) while simultaneously enriching the fields of learning sciences and educational technology (by studying MW in the context of cyberlearning). The research has provided usable data to refine theory while simultaneously tackling the critical problem of MW in STEM learning.

The broader impacts of the research are to promote interdisciplinary training of students, to broadening impact to underrepresented groups, to increase outreach, and to advance science education, intelligent learning environments, and human-computer interfaces. With respect to the first broader impact, the project has supported training of three postdoctoral researchers, six graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and one high-school student. Students were trained in the interdisciplinary fields of computer science, cognitive psychology, and the learning sciences. The project supported three PhD dissertations, two more are in progress, and some of the undergraduate students who participated in the research are now enrolled in graduate school. With respect to broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, more than 75% of the postdocs and students working on the project have been women. The project has increased outreach by working with five local high-school STEM teachers and with one high-school student who closely participated in the research. We also engaged with almost 500 high-school students through our core research activities and conducted information/discussion sessions about careers in STEM research with several of these students.

Finally, the project has benefitted society through its emphasis on developing cyberlearning technologies to facilitate learning biology. A strong foundation in biology is not only crucial for aspiring biologists and medical professionals, but is also instrumental for success in emerging STEM fields such as neuroscience, bioinformatics, and biomedical engineering. The project also led to the first fully-automated detectors of mind wandering for classroom environments and the first attention-aware cyberlearning technology that improves learning by combating wandering minds. Thus, the present focus on applying advances in attention-aware cyberlearning to help all students to learn STEM at deeper levels of mastery will have broad impacts in educating the next generation of professionals and scientists.
